Literature Review: The Challenge–Hindrance Stressor Framework (CHSF) has significantly contributed to our understanding of workplace stress by distinguishing between challenge and hindrance stressors. Challenge stressors, such as high workload or time pressure, are perceived as opportunities for personal growth and achievement, whereas hindrance stressors, such as role ambiguity or organizational politics, are perceived as obstacles to personal growth and achievement (Cavanaugh, Boswell, Roehling, & Boudreau, 2000). This distinction is crucial because it suggests that not all job demands are detrimental to employees; some can actually be beneficial. However, the CHSF has faced criticisms and limitations that hinder its potential. This literature review aims to address these criticisms and lay the foundation for the next iteration of this framework—CHSF 2.0. One major criticism of the CHSF is the assumption that all individuals appraise stressors in the same way. The Transactional Theory of Stress (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984) posits that stress is a result of an individual's appraisal of a situation as threatening or challenging. This theory suggests that individual differences, such as personality traits and coping strategies, can influence how stressors are appraised. For example, individuals with high levels of resilience may appraise hindrance stressors as challenges rather than threats (Smith, Dalen, Wiggins, Tooley, Christopher, & Bernard, 2008). Another criticism is the potential for negativity bias in the CHSF. Negativity bias refers to the tendency to give more weight to negative experiences than positive ones (Baumeister, Bratslavsky, Finkenauer, & Vohs, 2001). This bias may lead to an overemphasis on the negative effects of hindrance stressors and an underestimation of the positive effects of challenge stressors. To address this, future research should consider the role of positive psychology in the CHSF, focusing on how positive emotions and strengths can mitigate the negative effects of hindrance stressors and enhance the positive effects of challenge stressors (Seligman & Csikszentmihalyi, 2000). The Conservation of Resources (COR) theory (Hobfoll, 1989) provides another lens through which to view the CHSF. According to COR theory, individuals strive to obtain, retain, and protect their resources, and stress occurs when these resources are threatened or lost. Challenge stressors may be perceived as opportunities to gain resources, whereas hindrance stressors may be perceived as threats to resource loss. Future research should explore how resource gain and loss processes influence the effects of challenge and hindrance stressors. Cross-cultural research is another area that needs attention in the CHSF. Cultural differences can influence how stressors are appraised and managed. For example, collectivist cultures may place more emphasis on group harmony and social support, which can buffer the negative effects of hindrance stressors (Triandis, 1995). Future research should examine how cultural factors influence the CHSF and develop culturally sensitive interventions. Finally, the Job Demands–Resources (JD-R) model (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007) offers a complementary perspective to the CHSF. The JD-R model suggests that job demands can lead to strain, whereas job resources can lead to motivation. Integrating the CHSF with the JD-R model can provide a more comprehensive understanding of how job demands and resources interact to influence employee well-being. In conclusion, the CHSF has made significant contributions to our understanding of workplace stress, but it faces several criticisms and limitations. Addressing these issues and integrating insights from other theories and models can lay the foundation for CHSF 2.0, providing a more nuanced and comprehensive framework for understanding and managing workplace stress.
